body:
> It looks like you have a duplicate commit of the same thing though. A quick rebase, dropping one of the commits should fix this:
> -- remove one of the commits. If using VIM: "dd" one of the commits and then ":wq"

Please don't drop one of the commits, @mikewalch is correct.   Sorry you will lose one of your changes if you drop one of the commits.

I was thinking we could use `job.addCacheFile(uri);`
I found this [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21239722/hadoop-distributedcache-is-deprecated-what-is-the-preferred-api).
I just saw your comment on #894 .  Yeah I can't seem to find any recommendations for JobConf so we might have to do something like that... ugh :man_facepalming:
@jzgithub1 Looks good!  I will merge this.
I think this can now be closed.  Several PRs were completed to fix this.

> Could `t2` be inlined like you had it when passing scan time to finish?

Like this e446ba4 ?

The authorizations are stored in ZooKeeper, which can take some time to propagate changes if you're cluster size is greater than 1. It's possible that the internal ZK cache is not being expired and retried when it fails the first time in this case. Does it work if you wait a minute or two after changing the authorizations? Or when you have a single-node cluster?

Also, it would be helpful if we could see a visibility expression on a successful scan.

If you can provide a small example project which reproduces the error, that could help troubleshoot it, also.

This is on single node cluster only. And following is the output for a new user viz2 for which i set the authorization through the java call and the error and then i setauths on command line and then the successful scan :-

Hi @jzgithub1 . Thanks for the patch. I don't have time right this moment to review this (it seems others are on it anyway), but I did want to jump in quickly to comment on your git log messages, because I noticed that this pull request and the one in #901 both had long enough subject lines in the git commit log that GitHub wrapped them into the body.

Chris Beams had a good blog post about creating git log messages at https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ that I often refer people to.

For example, the log message on this issue could be improved similarly to:

```
Fix #810 Use builtins to redirect console in mini

Use Java ProcessBuilder.redirectOutput() instead of custom code to redirect
console output for processes launched by MiniAccumuloCluster.
```
This is to avoid https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-12974

I think the Java API is being used incorrectly. I think authorizations are being set as below:

```java
client.securityOperations().changeUserAuthorizations("user", new Authorizations("b0,b1,b2,b3,b4,b5,b6,b7");
```
This creates a single `b0,b1,b2,b3,b4,b5,b6,b7` authorization instead of several authorizations (i.e `b0`, `b1`, `b2`, etc).  If you are setting multiple auths, your code should be as follows:

```java
client.securityOperations().changeUserAuthorizations("user", new Authorizations("b0", "b1", "b2", "b3", "b4", "b5", "b6", "b7");
```
Accumulo should have probably never allowed commas `,` in authorizations to prevent this problem but this probably can't be changed now.  At a minimum, we could print auths better in the shell so you know if you are looking at one or multiple auths.  

Let me know if this was your issue
Allowing commas is okay... but the shell should definitely escape them when it prints them, to make it easier to debug.
Glad I checked in what I did without over thinking the issue.  I did not spend too much time on this so don't worry.
Merged changes in 2d634f2a330e8f1b7f925b744770f65da0eab037
Thanks @ctubbsii and @mikewalch for your responses. Will test and update here.
I will work on this.
@milleruntime  442fce0 is what I was thinking about for inlining.

Yes this indeed fixed the issue. I had even thought of this issue to be authorization being set as a full string but because setauths -u viz2 -s "b0","b1","b2" threw syntax error i did not go that route to pass the values in double quotes in java. But i should have thought that there could be difference in how api would work and try out anyways as i tried few other things. Anyways thanks again for helping me find a resolution for my issue. 

Also i agree as you both suggested there should be better way of showing the authorizations for debugging.
@jzgithub1, I think @ctubbsii is right that this shouldn't be fixed.  Sorry about that.  Thanks for working on it.

> While working on #786 I noticed that it would be nice to move CachedConfiguration into ClientContext.

I will work on this.  Are you thinking to drop CachedConfiguration completely and just store the hadoop conf in ClientContext?  Or just store a hadoopConf = CachedConfiguration.getInstance() in the ClientContext constructor?
No problem Mike.
See #901
This was done in #897
This was done in #893

@cjmctague thanks for the contribution but this is not _quite_ what I had in mind with the refactor.  I was thinking only have calls to the constructor and then the assignWork() method, which is the typical behavior of the class.  The assignWork() method should do the work to initialize the workQueue and create the zooCache, instead of just setting them directly in the test.  This will require more mocking up of objects like ZooUtil but it would be a more realistic test.
I have not looked at the test.  I still want that to do that.
@ctubbsii Can you check this PR and get this in with the release?  With this update the tool should report 0 maven dependency vulnerabilities upon release.
My vote would be to drop CachedConfiguration entirely. Just access it from the context as: getHadoopConfiguration()

Glad you got it resolved. Thanks for asking the question! If anybody's is interested in improving the display output for this in the shell, please feel free to submit a pull request with a proposed solution, or open a new issue to discuss potential solutions.
@milleruntime Sorry for the misunderstanding. Can you clarify the use case you are talking about for the more realistic case as well as the "Mock" up of ZooUtil

> @milleruntime Sorry for the misunderstanding. Can you clarify the use case you are talking about for the more realistic case as well as the "Mock" up of ZooUtil

No worries.  The EasyMock stuff can be weird and I am probably not doing a great job explaining it.  So please don't hesitate to ask more questions :+1:

I will continue to investigate and assume there was a regression.
https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/897#issuecomment-455696981
I think I can get the old hash code back.  I think I still own this bug.

@jzgithub1 with the test timeout you saw, its possible that the native maps were not built.  These can be built by running `mvn package -DskipTests`.  After this is done the IT may not hang.  If you ever run `mvn clean` then this will delete the native maps and `mvn package` will need to be run again.

@jzgithub1  I think I know what needs to be done to fix this. I can take a crack at it.
Thanks.  I appreciate that.

I have ran into a few road blocks for eliminating CachedConfiguration. Places where we can't easily pass a config and is widely used.

First is [here](https://github.com/milleruntime/accumulo/blob/dbfbfe88f4e1e5d2c1ccd96bbde988d4c16b34b6/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/conf/SiteConfiguration.java#L114) in SiteConfiguration.  The way we do things, we need the SiteConfiguration first to create ServerContext.

Second is [here](https://github.com/milleruntime/accumulo/blob/c7a54c80b937fd606ebdd6b3672f837f65b6258f/server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/fs/VolumeManagerImpl.java#L261) in VolumeManager.  Used everywhere and is treated as quasi API.  

These 2 situations appear to be the biggest hurdles.

Update: with my latest changes in #912, these 2 areas are now the only places left where we use CachedConfiguration.
I opened #911
Merged in 1bb6226

Could you make this more concise by just saying "at the moment this method was called".

Was this some kind of user-complaint? The examples you included seem obvious to me for any database.
I will work on this.
I'm taking over this issue from @jzgithub1

> Was this some kind of user-complaint? The examples you included seem obvious to me for any database. Not a complaint but used poorly. I have seen users make decisions based on the outcome like: 
tableOps().delete(t1)
... do some stuff
if (tableOps().exists(t1))
   throw Exception()

> Not a complaint but used poorly. I have seen users make decisions based on the outcome like:

I'm not sure I see the value in the addition then. If you're using a database in isolation, the semantics are obvious. But, if you're using a shared system, then of course other folks might do stuff that messes with you. Seems like it would be opening up a rabbit hole to me.

> > Not a complaint but used poorly. I have seen users make decisions based on the outcome like:
> 
> Seems like it would be opening up a rabbit hole to me.

I agree with adding the clarification to the documentation, but there maybe more we can do with the underlying issue.  This could be handled by keeping #768 open, or creating a new feature request.  

Some background - it seems this issue was triggered by recent changes in the zookeeper caching that changed client behavior and increased the time (minutes) before clients would see table changes (additions in this case.) The scenario:

Process 1 creates a table, performs a bulk import and stores created table name externally for clients.

Client1..n use the external name to scan the table.

The clients were defensively coded, using exits() before starting the scan, throwing errors if exists() returned false. With the changes / additions of zookeeper caching in the client, the period while the table existed, but not "known" to the client in the cache increased, with the delay now possibly being minutes.

The use of exists() seemed reasonable because tables are externally managed and if the external processes where not managing tables as expected, the exists() check could detect this upfront before starting a scan. 

In this case, the "fix" was to remove the check and instead rely on the scanner to determine if the table exists. Because the scanner / tservers handle the zookeeper caching differently than the client, (IIRC, they clear the cache and retry) the issue was mitigated.

Caching is an internal implementation and clients do need to understand that these types of conditions can and will occur in a distributed system, but we may be able to reduce the period while this condition exists.

Clarifying the documentation helps, but we should consider adopting the scanner strategy for exists() where it will automatically checks with zookeeper on a cache miss and updates the cache entry, or clears the cache more aggressively. (Less desirable because it's exposing internals would be to to provide clients a clearCache() or clearAndCheckExists() method.)

> Some background - it seems this issue was triggered by recent changes in the zookeeper caching that changed client behavior and increased the time (minutes) before clients would see table changes (additions in this case.)

Woah. That's... bad. I'd expect the upper-bound on this to be a couple of seconds, not multiple minutes. What's the change you're referencing, @EdColeman?
I think it may be related to the changes in https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/364  If not this specific change it was around this section of code.  Need to look more to verify this.

The UnsatisfiedLinkError should have been handled by the native-loading code in the Hadoop compression library we're using, and transformed into an IOException or another (non-Error) Exception. We might want to file a bug in upstream Hadoop regarding this... because the Hadoop compression API shouldn't be exposing the native code loading behavior from its internals via this Throwable.

OK so my changes in b04b91c are similar to what was done in 1.8, prior to the ID cache map change. This will obviously eliminate the benefits of having a cache for this method.  I am not sure what to do since reverting will cause performance to regress for use cases like Fluo with lots of lookups but not many create/drop tables.  @EdColeman 's use case is the opposite, where there are many create/drop tables but they want the table exists to be more accurate.  

Maybe we revert the functionality of the exists method to 1.8 behavior and create a new method that uses cached table IDs?
These should block 2.0 if they are reproducible.

I did a little more git log research...
5adeb4b7ed561a0bcea1a1def17835310831662f
ACCUMULO-4778 Cache table name to id map (#364)
This commit was done in the 1.9.0 and forward.  So the behavior of the exists method in 1.8.1 (and prior) was to check the ZooCache every time. 

The more I think about it, I think we should revert the behavior of this method back to just using the ZooCache, like we did in 1.8.1.  I feel this is a good compromise.  Other areas of Accumulo will gain the benefits of the cache but the behavior of this method will go back to what was expected in previous releases.  

Anyone else have thoughts on this?

Does it make more sense to move it to o.a.a.core.data package?  Part of the reason we put it in a Table class was so we could eventually create a Table API within it.

> Does it make more sense to move it to o.a.a.core.data package? 

What in the public API would use it?  I don't think it makes sense to have it in the public API if nothing uses it.

> Does it make more sense to move it to o.a.a.core.data package?

I think there is a compelling reason to have the type in the SPI now because internal plugins are given table IDs.  Currently in the public API tableID are never used for any operations and are only available for informational purposes.  I think it it would only make sense to have a table ID type in the API if non-informational APIs needed it.
There is a conflict that needs to be resolved.

> > Does it make more sense to move it to o.a.a.core.data package?
> 
> What in the public API would use it? I don't think it makes sense to have it in the public API if nothing uses it.

Nothing right now.  I was saying that if we are going to have a public Table class, wouldn't it make sense to have it with the other data classes like Key and Column.  The SPI packages would be the only thing that uses it now.  If you put Table in the SPI and if we ever come up with a Table API then we would have two Table classes one in SPI and one in with the data classes.  

A class like ScanInfo in the SPI would depend on org.apache.accumulo.core.data.Table like it does now with org.apache.accumulo.core.data.Column
I don't think its a good idea to put it in the API now with nothing in the API using it.  If we do use it in the API in the future, we may want do things differently when we actually try to use it.
@keith-turner, you should update https://accumulo.apache.org/docs/2.x/getting-started/table_configuration#compaction-strategies

It may make sense to have something in the public API in the future, but that is not something I would want to take on for 2.0.  I can see how possibly having an API and SPI table id type in the future could be problematic.

However we may never have the type in the API or the SPI and as a result SPI code may be  buggier.

I'll hold off on this for now.

My intent for this ID type was always to have it in the public API (as an immutable strongly typed surrogate for the human-readable "string" ID), but was holding off until it could be included as part of  first-class citizen `Table` and `Namespace` object representation of a table (or namespace). (example: create table could return a `Table`, and you could do things like `table.renameTo(newName)`, `table.scan()`, and `table.getId()`), but I didn't think that the ID would be useful by itself, so when @milleruntime worked on it, I suggested he keep it internal only for now. But for SPI, it seems like there's a good reason to go ahead and make it public API.

I would be in favor of putting it in `o.a.a.core.data` as `TableId` and `NamespaceId`, getting rid of the abstract base class, and the removing it from its containing outer class (which can be removed).
